abstract: The court might reject a new $150 million settlement over the takeover of Merrill Lynch, which could send the case to trial.
snippet: The court might reject a new $150 million settlement over the takeover of Merrill Lynch, which could send the case to trial.
lead_paragraph: A federal judge left open the possibility on Monday that he might reject a new $150 million settlement between the Securities and Exchange Commission and Bank of America over the bank’s controversial takeover of Merrill Lynch, a move that could force the case to go to trial.

headline.main: Judge Questions Bank of America’s New Deal With S.E.C.
headline.print_headline: Judge Questions Bank of America’s New Deal With S.E.C.

abstract: The China Investment Corporation bought more than $9 billion worth of shares in companies like Bank of America and Apple.
snippet: The China Investment Corporation bought more than $9 billion worth of shares in companies like Bank of America and Apple.
lead_paragraph: SHANGHAI  Flush with cash despite the global economic downturn, China’s sovereign wealth fund quietly bought more than $9 billion worth of shares last year in some of the biggest American corporations, including Morgan Stanley, Bank of America and Citigroup.

headline.main: China Lists $9.6 Billion in Shares of U.S. Companies
headline.print_headline: In Disclosure to S.E.C., China Lists $9.6 Billion in Shares of U.S. Companies

byline.original: By David Barboza and Keith Bradsher

abstract: Bank regulators haven’t exactly covered themselves in glory. But an earlier defense against bank excesses ought to be their boards. It’s not an easy job, but directors could try harder to control risk-taking.
snippet: Bank regulators haven’t exactly covered themselves in glory. But an earlier defense against bank excesses ought to be their boards. It’s not an easy job, but directors could try harder to control risk-taking.
lead_paragraph: Bank regulators haven’t exactly covered themselves in glory. But an earlier defense against bank excesses ought to be their boards, Breakingviews says. It’s not an easy job, but directors could try harder to control risk-taking. Uncomfortable questions are welcome.

abstract: A federal judge left open the possibility on Monday that he might reject a new $150 million settlement between the Securities and Exchange Commission and Bank of America over the bank’s controversial takeover of Merrill Lynch, a move that could force the case to go to trial.
snippet: A federal judge left open the possibility on Monday that he might reject a new $150 million settlement between the Securities and Exchange Commission and Bank of America over the bank’s controversial takeover of Merrill Lynch, a move that could fo...
lead_paragraph: A federal judge left open the possibility on Monday that he might reject a new $150 million settlement between the Securities and Exchange Commission and Bank of America over the bank’s controversial takeover of Merrill Lynch, a move that might result in the case going to trial, Louise Story reports in The New York Times.

headline.main: Judge Questions Bank of America’s New Deal With S.E.C.

abstract: Standard & Poor’s lowered its credit rating outlooks on Bank of America and Citigroup to negative from stable on Tuesday, saying the government appeared less likely to provide a further bailout if either bank needed it in the future.
snippet: Standard & Poor’s lowered its credit rating outlooks on Bank of America and Citigroup to negative from stable on Tuesday, saying the government appeared less likely to provide a further bailout if either bank needed it in the future.
lead_paragraph: Standard & Poor’s lowered its credit rating outlooks on Bank of America and Citigroup to negative from stable on Tuesday, saying the government appeared less likely to provide a further bailout if either bank needed it in the future.

headline.main: S.&P. Issues Negative Outlooks for BofA and Citi

abstract: Former Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr., responding to a question from Warren E. Buffett, said Tuesday that the United States government would be repaid in full for the bailout money it gave to financial firms.
snippet: Former Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr., responding to a question from Warren E. Buffett, said Tuesday that the United States government would be repaid in full for the bailout money it gave to financial firms.
lead_paragraph: Former Treasury Secretary Henry M. Paulson Jr., responding to a question from the billionaire financier Warren E. Buffett, said on Tuesday that the United States government would be repaid in full for the bailout money it gave to the nation’s financial firms.

headline.main: Paulson Reassures Buffett on TARP Repayment
